this satellite shoots in an incredibly high resolution the images come through every ten minutes in multiple spectra so
of course we're just looking at the visible spectra here and so you can imagine and and and this is a of course

this has the resolution you can zoom up quite tight on Australia and so what the
Bureau of Meteorology did was they took this and they said well we can build like a little application where you
could actually like browse and kind of map style around Australia and then look at the cloud cover and then
kind of press play and then see the cloud cover for the last several hours actually moving so they'd written this
application and and then they don't they've done some performance testing
and done the numbers on how much bandwidth this was going to consume to release to the Australian public and
they came to an alarming conclusion because
bom.gov.au/climate/ahead and this one application was going to double that
amount of bandwidth so it was going to produce as much load as the whole of the rest of Banga value put together and so
they came to us and said well we've got this problem you know we want to launch this application you know but we rapidly need
to actually scale up and we're at capacity and our current data centers at capacity for network etc so how can we
do this and and and and it gets them the model that they kind of that they had in
mind more or less was something like this and and this is the way most people would think about the problem to begin
with so you know you've got updates coming through from the satellite you have to have a tile processor and
basically the top rest it takes you know a photo and obviously have to do some reprojection right because you're taking your photo and you have to reject it
back into a flat map tile and so the tile process would take that and then put it in some kind of cache and this is
a super common model alright so you've got occasion maybe the case is shared between multiple servers and maybe each
service got its own cache there's different ways of doing this but basically that kind of tile case then
has to get served out to the application and the application itself was like it's a JavaScript application right so it's
basically just all it's a web page with a bunch of JavaScript and that has to get served off some servers as well and
then of course you know then you could potentially put a you know content delivery network in front of it to
accelerate and so on but so this is not how you would build it on AWS
in fact the idea of having servers to serve all that stuff is actually just
not needed at all in this case in order to build that in fact pretty much all
you need is s3 so s3 is simple storage service the thing that people often miss
about it is essentially a server so you can turn on web access for an s3 bucket
s3 is scaled so that it holds it holds
billions of objects but it scales to millions of requests per second and you
can do it and so you get this sort of enormous global scale web server just by
turning on web access on an s3 bucket that's really significant because it meant essentially the tile processor
could still be one little server that was managed by the Bureau it would take the feeds generate the tiles
and just put them in s3 and the JavaScript application because it's a web page the JavaScript application
itself can also be served by s3 and so instead of having dozens of servers to
manage and scale and have auto scaling all this kind of stuff just put it in there three and have one little server
and if that one little server goes down actually there's no adage either so even the one server that they've got
it's not even critical for delivering the workload and then of course we still put shield and cloud front in front of
that solution if we had have done it today because this was a couple of years
ago now we actually would have used lambda for the tar processor so we've got lambda it was just function of as a

trigger a lambda function process the tiles put it back in the s3 bucket and then they'd be available to serve and so

things came emergency management Victoria where we have a kind of an
agency that really crosses the different emergency services and provides central coordination and also notification to
the public so emergency management Victoria are responsible for notifying
Victorians now of actually any kind of emergency not just bush fires and one of
the things that was identified in the Royal Commission was that the the old IT systems actually didn't scale in the
event of an emergency and that was one of the contributing factors now so the
env website and mobile application you know it's really neat you can go in you
can register say who where you live also say maybe you've got a holiday house so you're interested in you know your mum

so you can go in you log in you you know you say that's an area you care about and then if say a fire happens they then

million people in a couple of minutes now when they first brought this
workload to us they they did kind of take the the older
architecture that they had and kind of put it on cloud and they've got a lot of benefits out of that they got auto
scaling and so they had a solution you know that would scale and meet the sort
of the large-scale needs of the public but it looked something kind of like this this is like a simplified version
they had about sort of 25 servers five load balancers there was a lot of
complexity and they spent a lot of time worrying about and you can kind of see this in the bottom half a lot of time
worrying about different copies of databases and a reads and write copies and they had quite a complicated process
that in the event that you had a data center fail you know that it would do a
failover to the other data center and so they kind of picked up their old active-passive dr model as well you know

deal of complexity but in the end you know an incident feeds in one side and then ultimately notifications feed out
the other side they did a sort of a largely engineering project to say well
okay we're going to rewrite this so that it's cloud native and and this is what it looks like today so today if someone
someone logs on to register on the website that whole website is served to them off s3 and then they fill out a
form and there's some Java Script which got served off s3 and they submit the form and the results of that actually go
into an RDS database and so they do have an odious database because they need some spatial queries right so they've
got a Postgres database which runs the the Postgres spatial extensions and so
so that user data gets stored in there when an incident happens an incident
actually gets treated as as a thing that winds up as a Geo JSON in s3 and that
triggers lambda functions and so the lambda functions is like a sort of array of lambda functions and then that then
worries about querying the database and finding out who I need to notify then using SNS to go ahead and you know
notify all those people but so they're using all these native AWS services and they have
literally one server remaining that they manage themselves and it managed their
content management system and so they've got a CMS and a person logs on and actually can to do updates in the CMS so
whatever they do actually just gets published to s3 and so that CMAs server can actually go down and it has no
impact on the system and all of the things you see outside the VP see
outside the stuff that they kind of have to manage themselves there are regional services and so you put something in s3

can imagine this is a real nightmare of an IT workload because for most of the year this system is practically unused
through a winter when there's nothing wrong there's no emergencies happening you know this is an IT system that just
lies dormant and so from a cost point of view it's terrific to have it lying
dormant using lambda because you don't actually pay for anything they're paying essentially for the database and all of
the other stuff is just literally unused but doing it the conventional way you've also got a system where 90% of the year
it's unused and then suddenly this is massive peak load and it absolutely has to work and lives depend on it
and so this takes away a whole level of worry about the IT infrastructure that
this system runs on but this this evolution that you see from having lots
of servers in a V PC to having a small number and leveraging native services it
means you get an application that's more resilient and and it's also much more
